questions.text: Who provided the voice for Underdog?
questions.explanation:
Wally Cox.

	Cox was also famous for his role as Mr. Peepers. The Detroit Michigan native appeared regularly in "Hollywood Squares" and appeared in more than twenty motion pictures.

Shoeshine Boy.

	Narrator George S. Irving always referred to our hero as the "humble and lovable" Shoeshine Boy.

questions.text: Whenever Underdog appeared he would proclaim, "There's no need to fear _________." Can you complete the phrase?
questions.explanation:
Underdog is here.

	The Underdog theme song, written by W. Walt Biggers became a pop culture classic. The first verse of the lyrics are... "When criminals in this world appear, And break the laws that they should fear, And frighten all who see or hear, The cry goes up both far and near for Underdog! Underdog! Underdog! Underdog! Speed of lightning, roar of thunder, Fighting all who rob or plunder Underdog, Underdog!"

questions.text: Where did Underdog go to get into his superhero costume?
questions.explanation:
A phone booth.

	When a crisis arose Underdog would jump into a phone booth to put on his red uniform and blue cape and would almost always destroy the phone booth when activating his super powers.

questions.text: Who was the "damsel in distress" that Underdog usually had to save?
questions.explanation:
Sweet Polly Purebred.

	Sweet Polly, whose voice was provided by Norma Macmillan, seemed to always get into trouble and would seek Underdog's help by singing in a high sad voice "Oh where, oh where has my Underdog gone" to the tune of "Oh Where, Oh Where has my Little Dog Gone".

questions.text: What was the occupation of the "damsel in distress" that Underdog seemed to save in every episode?
questions.explanation:
TV reporter.

	Being an aggressive television reporter Polly seemed to always get into trouble. Underdog never failed to respond to Sweet Polly's plea but unfortunately her admiration for Underdog never transferred to his other persona.

questions.text: In most episodes, when Underdog would take flight a crowd would look up and say, "Look in the sky! It's a bird! It's a plane!" After which one woman would shout "It's a(n) _______! Can you feel in the blank?
questions.explanation:
Frog.

	After declaring it's a frog, another onlooker would ask "A frog?"  Underdog would answer with one of his familiar rhymes, "not bird, not plane, not even frog. It's just little old me... (it is here that he would usually crash into a building or some other object) Underdog."

questions.text: What did Underdog have to do to acquire his superpowers?
questions.correct: Take an Underdog Super Energy Vitamin Pill
options: Recite his "There's no need to fear" mantra
Turn the switch on his Underdog Power Belt
questions.explanation:
Take an Underdog Super Energy Vitamin Pill.

	Underdog kept his power vitamin in a ring. In some episodes he lost the ring and was unable to acquire his powers until it was found. When the series was released in syndication in the 1980's and 1990's the part showing him taking his pill was edited out in what some said was overzealous political correctness. Others, however, thought the editing was needed because they beleived Underdog was glorifying drug use by taking the vitamin.

Simon Bar Sinister.

	Simon Bar Sinister was a mad scientist (voice by Allen Swift) who along with his cronies Riff Raff and Cad would wreak havoc on the local citizenry while trying to carry out their crimes. Occasionally Underdog fought other villains including The Electric (Slippery) Eel, Overcat and Battyman.

questions.text: A giant Underdog balloon appeared on which television show in 1994?
questions.explanation:
Friends.

	This was the ninth episode of Friends' first season. It was entitled "The One Where Underdog gets Away".  In this episode all the "Friends" for various reasons are forced to spend Thanksgiving together. When they go to the roof of the apartment to see the Underdog balloon that escaped from the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade they accidentally lock themselves out of the building and end up eating grilled cheese sandwiches and Funyuns which Chandler happened to have to celebrate his dislike for Thanksgiving. It first aired on NBC on November 17, 1994.
